Response: NA; we didn't have any changes

The high priority redesign interventions include, but are not limited to:  identifying and addressing patients social determinants of health and behavioral health needs prior to the procedure, along with the specific needs/services relating directly to the procedure; partnering with local social service resources; partnering with discharge planners at acute facilities and with key post-acute providers to deliver the most appropriate levels of care and services to drive the best clinical outcome for the patient; incorporating clinical best practices into daily routines; improving communications and flow of information between patients/providers/caregivers throughout the episode of care.

Successes: Working directly with local resources, we have assisted patients in procuring housing, adequate food and transportation critical to an optimal clinical outcome.  Barriers: The current CMS retrospective funding model for the BPCI-A shared savings presents significant challenges when funding the additional resources necessary to implement the program successfully.

Due to evolving changes in the BPCI-A terms and methodologies, delivering clear expectations of the benefits and obligations of participating providers in the program has been challenging. At this time, we have no providers enrolled in the program but we are actively recruiting providers to participate in the near future as Participating Providers.

Senior leaders departing the Participant prepare a written transition plan.  This plan is presented to the CEO and identified successor to ensure operations continue under new leadership.  Job descriptions outline the roles and responsibilities of positions to further aid in hiring and transitions.
Positive outcomes- physicians are far more aware of, and involved in, their patients' post-acute care and recovery.

We continually meet with, educate and monitor each provider to ensure that all eligible patients are timely enrolled in the program and are meeting program requirements.  Providers sign attestations certifying that they are in compliance with the program.
We have not experienced any issues associated with submitting required documentation.

Retrospective (instead of prospective) based reimbursement structure puts enormous strain on non-convener participants funding cost of proper operations, care support, and in evaluating additional resources necessary to implement appropriate care and other non-covered requirements for the patients. For example, the lack of a list of CPT codes qualifying under each DRG that would trigger services.  Furthermore, the delay in confirming eligible episodes and proper bundles creates too much uncertainty, coupled with the fact that we do not have DRG level Target Pricing information for each ACH creates unnecessary challenges to make appropriate and timely value based care-cost decisions for each episode.
